p:
High Miller index Cu surfaces exhibit varied relaxation sequences
6– 17, 20, 22, 24– 29, 31, 33 from which a general rule has been compiled, albeit still contentious
7, 31 . Low energy electron diffraction (LEED) analyses report no surface relaxation between the top atomic Cu(410) interlayers
17, 30 . On the other hand, ion scattering spectroscopy (ISS) measurements show large contraction between the first few Cu(410) layers
9 . Later investigations suggest that the pattern of relaxation sequences, in broad scale, complement each other. For the case of Ag(410), previous quantitative LEED (QLEED) analyses found no surface relaxation (neither expansion: +nor contraction: −, with respect to the bulk-truncated values) of the first interlayer spacing, and a (−; +) sequence for second and third interlayer spacings, respectively
34 .
